Award.AbstractNarration:
In understanding both the physical world and the mathematics that lies beyond its boundaries, geometry and symmetry are everywhere. This project seeks to advance our knowledge of abstract shapes that share two properties: positive curvature and global symmetry. The first of these is a requirement that the shape is curved in a manner similar to how the surface of a ball curves, the same way in all directions. The second means that the object looks the same when spinning, similar to how a football appears when thrown in a perfect spiral. The principal investigator studies shapes likes these through collaborations with other researchers, working with PhD students, and the organization of seminars and conferences.  In addition, through his outreach to high schools in Oklahoma and his involvement with undergraduates, the PI is committed to growing and diversifying the body of students and researchers in STEM fields.

The first aspect of this project is a continuation of the PI's work on the Grove symmetry program, which, in recent years, has exposed numerous instances of how positive curvature and symmetry can come together to force periodicity in the cohomology of the underlying manifold. The second aspect is a systematic study of topological realization problems involving the condition of periodic cohomology, especially in the presence of symmetry. There are already instances of results along these lines, and the proposal seeks to formalize this research program and find new paths toward advancing understanding in this area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Thanks to the generous support from the National Science Foundation, by way of this grant and other venues such as conference support and MSRI, the early-career PI has had multiple opportunities to engage with leading experts, peers, and students in his research area.

 

In Spring 2016, the PI spent the semester as a postdoc at MSRI thanks in part of NSF support. This led to the beginning of a collaboration with Burkhard Wilking (University of Muenster), who is a top expert in the PI’s research area. This collaboration was further supported by this grant through visits made to Germany and Australia to visit Dr. Wilking. In addition, the PI has been able to use grant funds to support a visit to the U.S. by Michael Wiemeler (University of Muenster), who is now collaborating on this project. Additional travel for this purpose was planned in 2020 but was regrettably canceled due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Nevertheless, the summer salary and equipment support provided by the grant allowed for the PI to continue work on this collaboration. This collaboration has led to the best work the PI has ever been involved in, and it would not have been possible without the support of the NSF.

 

The PI has also been able to sustain and develop additional collaborations with the help of these NSF funds. Specific examples include using these funds to support his collaborators Jason DeVito (University of Tennessee, Martin) and Catherine Searle (Wichita State University) to visit the PI in Syracuse, New York. In addition, the funds have supported fruitful trips to Germany, China, Australia, and elsewhere for conferences and opportunities to present research and to engage with others. In particular, the trip to China in Summer 2019 led to productive work with the PI’s collaborator Yusheng Wang (Beijing Normal University).

 

Finally, this grant has supported the PI’s first Ph.D. student, Elahe Khalili Samani (Syracuse University, Ph.D. expected 2021), in the form of conference travel. This has given her opportunities to present her results, some of which have already been published in a paper in the journal Transformation Groups. In addition, the PI has begun a pair of undergraduate research projects with SU undergraduates. One is with Yantao Wu (Syracuse University, B.S. expected 2021), who is applying to Ph.D. programs in mathematics this year. The other is with Can Luo and Bin Liao, two SU undergraduates who plan to graduate in 2021 and who are applying to M.S. programs in financial mathematics / financial engineering.
